Or we could still use PartitionNotFoundException but with a clearer message specifying we could not find a partition on which to execute this command successfully.

replies.bodyText: Not sure if "PartitionNotFound" is the right exception here. What we want to convey to the user is the request failed even after multiple retries. If all retries returns resource exhausted, is it really partition not found?  But I agree that the current message is also not clear.

replies.bodyText: Yeah, was just an idea 😅 RequestRetriesExhaustedException is also ok? I think for me it was more than RequestRetryFailed sounds like a single request, when what we mean is we have no more "retries" left.

timeline.bodyText: If there is no topology, nothing happens, right? So what happens to the gRPC request that triggered this? It is just left hanging, and eventually times out?
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Right. Nothing happens now and grpc request times out eventually. May be we can return a topology NOT_FOUND here.
replies.author: deepthidevaki

replies.bodyText: Hm, not sure. Is this what we return, NOT_FOUND, when there is no leader for a given partition? If so then yes, let's do that. If we know we can't do anything then let's immediately quit instead of waiting for a time out.
replies.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: For other requests, they timeout eventually while transport is trying to find the leader. So the response will be timeout. But here I now added 'NoTopologyAvailableException'
